text:
Hi guys, I'm Laura Vitale and on this episode
of Laura in the Kitchen, I'm going to show

you how to make - or how I make Ropa Vieja,
which is a Cuban slow cooked shredded beef

that is absolutely out of this world delicious,
it is so easy to make, I made this a couple

of weeks ago and I like to share a lot on
my Instagram stories and if you don't follow
me on Instagram, the link is down below.

You definitely should because a lot of time
I post things that I haven't yet posted on

Laura in the Kitchen, I don't know if I'm
going to and it's a great way for me to see
whether or not you're interested.

And I'll tell you what, I posted that recipe
that I had made for dinner in my stories and

everyone - I'm not even kidding, hundreds
of people were like 'Please show us the recipe,

please show us your take on it' because you
know it's not going to be authentic, but it

is going to be delicious, so let me run you
through the list of ingredients that you'll

need right now which are not many, but they're
all the right ones.

You need a good hunk of meat, I'm using chuck,
I think chuck works so well, and it's really
good on the budget as well.

You need lots of peppers, I've got red bell
pepper, Cubanelle pepper, yellow onion, lots

and lots of garlic, salt, cumin and oregano,
tomato paste and diced tomatoes, and you'll

need some beef stock and a little bit of olive
oil, light olive oil because I'm going to
sear this before I put it in my slow cooker.

This is so good, if you're eating low carb
it's great, if you're not it's fantastic,
whatever you're doing, it is money!

A nice big skillet with a little bit of olive
oil, I want it nice and hot because I'm going
to sear my meat.

Make sure that you season your beef really
well on both sides, and I'm going to put this

in here just to let it sear for, I would say
about a minute or two until you get really
good color.
Perfect!
That looks great!

Alright, now slow cooker time, this is so
easy because everything goes in the slow cooker

and it's amazing and it cooks for hours and
hours and hours, your home is going to smell
great, I mean what's better than that?

In your slow cooker, I am just going to add
- I'm going to do my wet mixture first so
I can season it.
I've got tomato puree and diced tomatoes.

I've got some beef stock, you can use chicken
broth if you want to but I think beef works
better.

Then I've got the oregano and the cumin, I
want to add a good pinch of salt because I

haven't seasoned the veggies yet, but we are
going to add some green olives to this at

the end and they're quite salty so you kind
of want to be careful not to add too, too

much but you do want every layer of your dish
to be well seasoned.
Okay, then you add your veggies.
This is going to be so good!

And then you just take your beef and you nestle
that right in.

And as this cooks, it's going to fall apart
and be absolutely phenomenal.

So what I'm going to do is - you can cook
this on high or low - I'm going to cook it

on high for about 5 hours or so or until the
meat starts to fall apart and get really tender

and lovely and I will show you what it looks
like when it is there.

I'm telling you this is so good, you're going
to have this on your recipe repertoire all

week long because it is really that good,
I promise.

So, my ropa vieja was cooking for almost five
and a half hours and I took the beef out,

I let it cool for a little bit and I took
two forks and I shredded it up and I discarded

all of the fat, now here is the base, here's
all of the juices and everything, it looks
delicious, it looks fantastic.

Now to this, this is really hot so I'm going
to put in the shredded beef that I shredded

with two forks and a little bit with my fingers
and it was hot!

What I have here are some pimento stuffed
green olives, now this is crucial in here

I think, and what I also have is a tablespoon
of the olive juice, you can also use white

vinegar if you want to, I love that briny-ness
so I'm just going to add that right in, and
you want to just give this a stir.
Oh it looks so amazing!

I already tasted this and it doesn't need
any additional salt, but you give it a taste,

if you feel like it needs more salt, then
by all means add more salt, now this looks

quite brothy, and you can serve it that way
or you can get rid of some of the juices.

I'm going to serve it that way because I plan
on serving mine with some white rice, but
look how beautiful this is all combined.

And he residual heat will warm up those olives
and then that flavor will really kind of permeate

through the juices and all of the meat and
all the veggies, but oh, this is so good,

you need to serve this with lots of cilantro
on top, freshly squeezed lime juice, like

I said, rice and beans and you will be in
food heaven, I promise.

One thing that I cannot stand, and it happens
all the time when I'm transferring something

into a platter is dirty edges on a platter,
so take your time.
I've got some more here to serve.
A little lime juice.
Over the top.

Then take some lime wedges, nestle them all
around, and look how good that looks!
Let's do three.

And then just some beautiful cilantro, just
roughly torn over the top because sometimes

I like the herb to be almost like another
ingredient not just like a decoration.
Especially in this case.

And then take a mapeen, which is just the
Italian word, or the Napolitano word for kitchen
towel.
And you just do that.

And that looks amazing and fantastic and everyone
is going to want to tuck in that, I know I'm

gonna do that right now a little pepper, a
little beef.
Gimme the olive!
Throwing down on that one!
Tender, melts in your mouth.
Perfect blend of spices.
Delectably seasoned.

That is a money maker and I want you to serve
this at your next get together, like I said

rice and beans makes everybody happy, it's
good on the wallet too, because you're using

a piece of chuck which is, you know feeds
an army and it's really good price point.
This will be the next get together food.
I promise.

I hope you've enjoyed spending time with me,
get the recipe on LauraintheKitchen.com and
I'll see you next time.
Bye bye!
